note: 9 x 14.5 cm; i (paper) + 14 + i (paper) folios on parchment; written in dark brown ink in a gothic bookhand; 1- to 4-line initials in blue, red, and gold; 4 5-line historiated initials in various colors and gold. 18 pages with historiated and decorated margins bearing the following: acanthus leaves, carnations, and other flowers; monkeys, birds, and a unicorn; wild men, a juggler, noblemen, and a lady; the shroud of Veronica, the Christ Child, Christ praying in Gethsemane, and Christ crucified. 20th-century dark pink buckram binding. (Source: dealer description)|See curatorial file for further information.

15 x 10 cm; i (parchment) + 142 (parchment) + 55 (paper) + i (parchment) folios; modern foliation in pencil, 1-142; printed section on paper with printed foliation, 2-56; watermark on paper includes grapes (?) but is not fully visible; collation impracticable but lacking circa 18 leaves; folios 1-2, 9, 20, 37 (on the upper part of the original leaf was replaced), 49, 55, 66, 73, 97, 103, 131, 137 were copied, painted, and inserted in 1885; no catchwords; ruled in red ink. Original sections: written in brown and red inks in gothic textualis bookhand on 14 lines, capitals touched in yellow wash, 1- to 2-line champie initials and line-fillers in burnished gold on dark pink and blue grounds decorated with white penwork, one 4-line initial in dark pink decorated with white penwork, infilled with bluebells on a burnished gold ground (folio 62), two floral rinceaux borders with small leaves in burnished gold (folio 37v, the upper part removed and replaced, and folio 62). Sections copied and decorated in 1885: written in black and red inks imitating gothic textualis bookhand on 14 lines, 1- to 2-line initials in liquid gold on pink/red and blue grounds with white decoration, 10 4-line initials in colors and liquid gold, two of which are inhabited by the figure of Christ, 11 floral rinceaux or acanthus borders in colors and liquid gold. Bound in 17th-century brown leather; front board detached. (Source: dealer description)|Fragile; front cover partially detached.|See curatorial file for further information.

note: Parchment scroll composed of 12 membranes of varying dimensions, pasted together end to end. Written in brown ink in at least 2 hands: 1. Gothic hybrida for most of the names appearing inside roundels. 2. Hybrid for longer passages outside roundels, blending Gothic hybrida and italic characteristics. All membranes laid out in 3 columns. Illuminations in green, brown, red, and gold. Some soiling, small tears and holes. Probably produced in or around London in the first quarter of the 16th century as a copy of a similar scroll held by the British Library, Add MS 63009.|See curatorial file for further information.|Purchased with the Louis J. Appell Jr. Fund for British Civilization, 2018.

Written in a good serto hand with estrangela features, in two columns, 25 lines per column, in black with rubrics in red and green.|Purchased by the Harvard Semitic Museum in 1922 (accession no. 8375) from Dr. F. Grote.|Semitic Museum deposit, ca. 1959.

Written in a fine small serto hand with some estrangela features (g q š especially), in black ink with some headlines and other small ornaments in red, 16 lines per page.|There are occasional marginal glosses in Greek in a neat uncial hand.|Date from colophon (photograph in Goshen-Gottstein, 149), restoring TLT Mʼʼ where a different word has been written over a rasura. The Patriarch "Athanasius" named there will be Athanasius Ṣalḥaya (986-1004) and the bishop "Isaac" will be Isaac of Callisura ordained by him.|Binding of full leather over wooden boards, with a flap. Velvet is pasted over the spine. The front and back boards are covered with plates of silvered brass, with repoussé images of Christ on the cross (back) and the Virgin and child with angels (front). The front image has an inscribed caption in Syriac script (but perhaps in Turkish).|In a tray case, 15 cm.|Formerly in the collection of J. Rendel Harris, his number "Cod. Syr. 115" being written on f. 2r. Purchased by the Harvard Semitic Museum in 1905 (accession no. 4050).|Semitic Museum deposit, ca. 1959.

title_as_recorded: The New Testament in the Syriac Peshitta version
note: Written in a small neat East Syriac estrangela hand with vowels, in black ink, with rubrications, in one column, 25 lines per column.|Sections are numbered in the margin according to the usual double series. title_as_recorded: The New Testament in the Syriac Peshitta version
note: A leaf is missing after f. 330.|In a tray case, 30 cm.|Written in a fine estrangela hand with East Syriac vowels, in one column, 26-28 lines per page. This changes to a serto in the middle of f. 333v. Rubrics, subscriptions and other occasional ornaments are in red and green.|Sections of the text are numbered in the margins using the usual double sequence. Lections are not marked. A later hand has added glosses and other unidentified words in small writing in the margins.|Date from colophon, which gives the date 1511 AG ( = 1199/1200) and the hijra date 594 ( = 1198/9).|The colophon also gives the scribe's name as Boktishoʻ and the place of writing the monastery of Rabban Sabrišoʻ in the mountains of Qardu.|There are notes in English translating various rubrics throughout the ms.|"Presented by the Nestorian Patriarch Mar Shimon to Doct. A. Grant and by him to the Library of the A.B.C.F. Missions" - f. 337v.|Oriental binding in full leather over walnut boards, fastened with a leather strap.|ABCFM deposit, ca. 1942.

Lawrence of Grand Rapids, Michigan.|Gift of Mrs. Mary Lawrence Loomis, in memory of her brother John S. Lawrence, 1924.

The text is written in a large gothic rotunda hand, with music on a red 4-line staff.|The initial letter "G" is historiated, showing a female saint in a Dominican habit, crowned, apparently Bd. Elizabeth of Hungary (d. 1320). This is drawn in tempera with gold leaf.|The illumination has been ascribed to the Master of the Dominican Effigies, working in Florence: see Palladino.|Gift of Robert Lehman to the Fogg Art Museum, 1943. Transferred to Houghton Library, 1990.

The initial letter "D" is historiated, with St. Paul holding book and sword. There is a foliate part-border, in which is the figure of a Dominican nun praying.|The initial and border are drawn in tempera with gold leaf. These have been attributed to Pacino di Bonaguida: see Palladino.|The text is written in a large gothic rotunda hand, in black with red rubrics, with music on a red 4-line staff. There are 2 initial letters on the verso in red and blue with pen-work decoration.|Gift of Robert Lehman to the Fogg Art Museum, 1943. Transferred to Houghton Library, 1990.

The miniature is in tempera, colored and gold inks, and gold leaf. It has been attributed to a follower of the Master of the Munich Golden Legend (active ca. 1430-1440). A previous attribution was to the circle of the Bedford Master. See curatorial file for both attributions.|"Our Saviour judging the world" - caption in a later hand at bottom of recto.|Gift of Sydney J. Freedberg to the Fogg Art Museum, in memory of Susan Pulitzer Freedberg, 1980. Transferred to Houghton Library, 1990.

title_as_recorded: Eclipses luminarium; summa fide et accurata diligentia supputatae, ac figuris coloribusque suis artificiose depictae, quarum rationes ab anno domini currente 1554, usque ad annum domini 1600 completum se extendunt, & ad Meridianum Neuburgi Danubiani referuntur
note: The text is written on the versos in Latin in an italic script, above a German translation in German cursive script.|On the rectos there are 61 diagrams in color showing the positions of the moon (or sun) before, during and after an eclipse. There are 7 other watercolor drawings showing scenes during eclipses.|The ms. is similar to but not the same as the printed edition (Augsburg 1556).|The title page has parallel titles in Latin and German. It contains a dedication to Duke Otto Heinrich of Bavaria. The date 1554 follows if this ms. is itself the presentation copy.|Bound in 18th-century half mottled calf and marbled paper.|In a tray case, 47 cm.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

title_as_recorded: Liturgy of St. Basil in Greek

Written and illuminated by Gottschalk for the Benedictine Abbey of Lambach In Austria.|For other leaves from this ms., including MS Typ 704 (6), see Davis, specif. 38-44.|The text is written in a carolingian minuscule hand in black ink, with unheightened neumes above the lines, also in black. Written in a late carolingian minuscule book hand in brown ink in long lines, rubrics in red daubed with yellow. The recto contains a 13-line initial "D" (in "Dixi custodiam vias meas") with vine-leaf decoration in violet, green and blue.|Probably German.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

Written in a gothic rotunda hand, with musical notation.|There are 43 historiated initials with foliate borders, by Lippo Vanni. Berry in New York in 1887 and bequeathed to the Fogg Art Museum, 1928.|Deposited by the Fogg Art Museum in Houghton Library, 1953; transferred, 1990.

The Latin text is written in a tall gothic book hand in black ink. Initial letters are in black and red with pen-work decoration. Musical notation is square black notes on a red 4-line staff.|The recto shows a large initial A historiated with the scene of the Presentation (Luke 2.25).|The top margin has old folio numbers 222 and 495. .|Another 3 leaves of this ms. are Morgan Library M.870.1, 2, 3.|Probably written at Regensburg, ca. 1310. The name "Gerwirch" is written beside an illumination on one of the Morgan leaves. This is likely the name of the female donor.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

note: The original document (ff. 1-15) is written in a gothic rotunda hand in black ink 1 column, with red rubrics. Written in Latin in a professional italic hand in brown ink, with signatures, date and endorsements in a secretary hand at the end. The names of the notaries Baltazare Mollery and Petrus Verliot appear at the end of the text.|F. 1r has an illuminated border incorporating the arms of the pope and emperor.|Sewn into an original cover of limp vellum.|In a tray case, 35 cm.|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; bequeathed, 1984.

title_as_recorded: Chronica darinnen die fürnembsten unnd namhafftigesten Geschichten aus gaistlichen unnd weltlichen Historien die sich vor unnd nach Christi geburt bis anno 1569 verlauffen und den merern faill zu Augspurg zugetragen auffs Kurtzest verfasst unnd beschriben worden

There are 3 other illuminated initials.|Bound in 19th-century red morocco (in an older style) stamped on front and back with the arms of Cardinal de Bourbon.|In a tray case, 39 cm.|Purchased with the fund for Printing and Graphic Arts given by Philip Hofer, 1956.

former_owner_as_recorded: Gentile di Giuseppe, F|Salem, Adriana R

The leaves are all more or less stained and some are loose.|The contents are identical with British Library MS Egerton 681, written by the same scribe.|Two fragments of leaves from liturgical mss. are inserted before f. 1. (One is adhering to f. 1.)|Written in a bold and elegant estrangela in red and black. Words are supplied with vowel-points and marks of cantillation. The text is in two columns, 19 lines per column.|Bound in oriental full leather with blind stamping on front and back. The leather has perished over the spine exposing a cloth lining to which the headbands are sewn.|In a tray case, 39 cm.|Purchased by the Harvard Semitic Museum from J. H. title_as_recorded: Livre de la chass; with Llull's Livre de l'ordre de chevalerie
author_as_recorded: Gaston III Phœbus, Count of Foix, 1331-1391
former_owner_as_recorded: Brugge, Lodewijk van, heer van Gruuthuse, approximately 1427-1492|Gonthaut-Saint-Blanchard family|Louis XII, King of France, 1462-1515
note: Written by Jan van Kriekenborch at Ghent in 1485 (f. 1v and colophon). The French text is in littera bastarda in two columns, with many illuminated initals and line-fillers.|The two works are housed in separate 4-flap enclosures within a tray case, 44 cm.|"En ce livre sont contenus trois livres. C'est a savoir. Le premier le livre de la chasse nomme le Conte Phebus. Le second livre du jeu des eschiecs moralizie. Le tiers est le livre de chevalerie. Comment on doit faire chevalerie et comment il doit vivre et soy gouverner" - f. 1v.|The treatise on chess is missing from the present manuscript, or was never part of it. An old series of folio-numbers is almost continuous (only missing 2 leaves) between the two surviving works.|There are 1 large and 85 small miniatures by the Master of the Flemish Boethius (MS Bibliothèque Nationale MS néerl. 1). The foliate border on f. 101v includes the device of Louis de Bruges and the arms (added later) of Louis XII of France.|This manuscript is a companion to MS Typ 129. Both were made for Louis de Bruges (Lodewijk van Brugge).|Louis XII of France; Gontaut-Saint-Blanchard family (1873).|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; presented, 1982.

author_as_recorded_agr: سيرافي، الحسن بن عبد الله، approximately 893-approximately 979
note: Written in one column, 18 lines per pages, in black ink.|The ms is incomplete and contain the following sections (ajzāʼ): section 43 (f. 1r), 58 (f. 32r), 70 (f. 60r), 67 (f. 69r), 68 (f. 119r), 76 (f. 231r), 77 (f. 261r), 80 (f. 319r). There are also parts from other sections, which lack title pages. Leaves may be out of order.|Bound in light brown leather. Bound in India probably in late 19th or early 20th century.|The ms is not dated but copied in the life time of the author, towards the end of it, and most probably in Baghdad. The book was read to the author and signed by him.|Note in the hand of the author on f. 1r and on first folios of each juzʼ of the book: "qaraʼahu ʻalayya ilá ākhirihi Abū Muḥammad al-Ḥasan ibn ʻAlī al-Madāyinī; wa-katabahu al-Ḥasan ibn ʻAbd Allāh al-Sīrāfī."|With this is bound a fragment of the section on letter bāʼ (colophon title: Kitāb al-bāʼ) of a dictionary (ff. 356-365). The author of the dictionary is identified as Abū ʻAbd Allāh Muḥammad ibn Jaʻfar al-Tamīmī al-Naḥwī in the colophon (f. 365v). The fragment is completed in the hand of the ʻAlī ibn al-Ḥasan ibn Abī Ḥanīfah on 4 Rajab 368 AH [February 3, 979 AD]. The manuscript was collated with the original one written in the hand of the author.|Iran Jewett manuscript no. 1.|Transfer from Widener, 2010.|Gift of Mrs. Iran Jewett, 2009.

The text is written in a carolingian minuscule hand, with neumes above each line, arranged around a single red staff line.|The recto contains a large foliated initial "T" in red and yellow.|Probably Italian, to judge from resemblance to Lucca, Biblioteca Capitolare, ms. 601.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

Written in a large minuscule book hand in black ink in 2 columns, 28 lines per column. Written area 215 x 160 mm.|On the recto is a 9-line zoomorphic initial "H", the curved part composed of a dragon with curling neck; in red and white, the head and wings in brown, on a blue background.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

Written and illuminated by Gottschalk for the Benedictine Abbey of Lambach In Austria.|For other leaves from this ms., including Houghton MS Typ 704 (5), see Davis, specif. 38-44.|The text is written in a carolingian minuscule hand in black ink, with unheightened neumes above the lines, also in black. Rubrics are in red.|The initial U of the antiphon "Veni sponsa Christi" is historiated in orange and purple, showing a crowned figure.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

title_as_recorded: Graduale dominicale et feriale totius anni
subject_as_recorded: Georgius, of Vicomercato|Bassianus, of Glisate|Lodi (Italy)--Church history
note: Written in a gothic rotunda hand in black ink with red rubrics, the chant in black on a red 4-line staff. Initial letters are in red and blue with pen-work decoration.|On the recto is a historiated initial "A" (beginning the antiphon "Ad te levavi animam meam") in gold paint and colors, showing David praying, with Christ above, being viewed from the side by a bishop and choir of friars. The initial continues into a foliate page-border.|Title from superscription on recto. This continues: "Fecit fieri venerabilis do. Basianus de glisate prepositus ecclesie maioris sci basiani in laude ... quod scripsit et notavit frat. georgius de vicom[er]cato ordinis minorum. Inceptum die pm. a decemb. m.ccccv." That is, the ms. was written for Bishop Bassianus of Glisate and the church of St. Bassianus in Lodi, by George of Vicomercato, O. F. M., and begun on 1 Dec. 1405.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

scribe_as_recorded_agr: اردبيلي، محمد بن يحيى بن احمد،
note: Title from f. 1r.|According to colophon (f. 60v), copy completed in Tabrīz in Rajab 551 AH [August 1156 AD] in the hand of Muḥammad ibn Yaḥyá ibn Aḥmad al-Ardabīlī.|Written in two columns, from 16 to 18 lines per page, in black ink. Each column framed within double golden or grey now faded lines.|There is numerous aniconic headpieces in colors and gold and 16 miniatures.|On inside back cover: "Purchased for Philip Hofer in Tehran as an example of 12th century illumination and presented as such to the Harvard College Library. Subsequently doubts arose as to its authenticity and it was submitted to experts for examination."|Persian poems.|Formerly owned by Philip Hofer.
With: Hādhihi al-qaṣīdah al-musammāh bi-Lāmīyat al-ʻajam / lil-Ṭughrāʼī.

Written in an unidentified hand, probably in mid-16th cent. Persia, in a nastaʻlīq script in red and black ink, with 4 gold-ruled columns and some decorated borders in blue, red, and gold. Written in an italic hand in brown ink, 15 lines per page, initials and rubrics in red and blue.|The ms. is foliated 1-171, but ff. 144, 147-152, 169-170 are stubs only and f. 171 is blank. About 7 leaves, not foliated, are stubs only after f. 67.|Written for use in Venice, as shown by the kalendar (ff. 1-12) which is in the Venetian dialect of Italian and includes Venetian observances.|There are full-page miniatures on ff. 14v, 72v, 94v, 136v, and 141v. The kalendar includes 12 small zodiacal miniatures. There are 5 leaves with foliate borders and historiated initials, and 8 historiated initials.|The miniatures have been identified as the work of Benedetto Bordon.|Bound in original silver gilt over wooden boards, with a clasp. The spine has 5 parallel hinges. Front and back boards have 4 bosses and a roundel in the center with the initials DINT (front) and SMF (back).|At the bottom of f. 15r is a coat of arms, argent 4 bends gules.|In a cloth case with ribbon ties, 10 cm.|Bequest of Nettie G. Naumburg to the Fogg Art Museum, 1930. Transferred to Houghton Library, 1990.

physical_description: Extent: 1 leaf : vellum ; 17 cm., mounted to 37 x 27 cm.
note: Written in an angular gothic book hand, 17 lines to the page, within a Flemish-style illusionistic border of fruit, flowers, birds and insects on a gold painted ground.|On the recto is a 7-line miniature of the deposition from the cross in tempera, colored inks and gold paint.|Mounted: the verso is not visible.|Gift of Robert Lehman to the Fogg Art Museum, 1943. Transferred to Houghton Library, 1990.

former_owner_as_recorded: Bateman family|Morris, William, 1834-1896|Hodson, Laurence W|Beatty, A. Chester Sir, 1875-1968
note: Written in an early gothic minuscule hand in black ink in 2 columns, 52 lines per column.|Large decorated initial letters in various colors mark the opening of each Psalm. Smaller initials are in red or blue.|From internal evidence, probably written in Germany.|Probably the last volume of an original 3-volume set.|Marginal numbers i, ii, iii indicate the opening words of lections at matins.|There are extensive corrections in later hands.|Single leaves are wanting before f. 1 and after f. 56. Some leaves are misbound, the correct order being 1-6, 9-56, 59, 8, 57, 58, 68-156, 60-67, 157-178 (according to old cataloging).|Bound in 19th-century blind-stamped brown calf over wooden boards, rebacked.|In a tray case, 52 cm.|Bateman of Middleton Hall, Derbyshire (bookplate; "Bateman heirlooms" sale, Sothebys 25 May 1893, lot 233); William Morris (bookplate; his sale, Sothebys 5 Dec. 1898, lot 148); Laurence Hodson of Compton Hall (bookplate; his sale, Sothebys 3 Dec. 1906, lot 28); Sir A. Chester Beatty (spine label "W.MS.V" = MS 129; his sale, Sothebys 24 June 1969, lot 45).|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

Written in black ink in two columns in more than one minuscule hand. Individual books begin with large initial letters in red and yellow.|Probably written at the Abbey of Morimondo near Pavia in Italy, to judge from decoration, binding and modern provenance (see Light, 53-54).|J. Martini (Lugano, Switzerland), catalogue 22 (1931), no. 9.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

Written in a Benventan script of the "Bari" type, in dark brown ink in 2 columns, 29 lines per full column.|Probably written in Puglia (old cataloging).|The recto contains the epistle Ro 6.5-11 (incomplete at the beginning), alleluia and gradual Diligam te Domine with neumes, gospel Luke 14.16-24, and offertorium in a later hand. The initial of the gospel reading is historiated with an ox.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

title_as_recorded: Ein gutte ordnung; und kurze unterricht der furnembsten grunde aus denen die Jungen zierlichs schribens begirlich mit besonnderer kunst unnd behenndigkait unterricht und geubet mogen werden / Durch Johann Newdorffer Burger und Rechenmaister zu Nurmberg seinen schulern zu mererm verstanndt geordnet ; und durch mich Philip Stos mit fleis nachgemacht ; im jar der geburt Jhesu Christi unnsers herren und seligmachers MDlv

physical_description: Extent: 23 leaves, bound : vellum ; 21 x 29 cm.
note: The texts are written in German in various blackletter and German cursive scripts except on ff. 10v-13r, 23r (Latin in blackletter, roman and italic).|Written in black ink (except for ff. 12v-13r in red), flourished with gold, on the recto and verso of ff. 1-19 and the rectos only of ff. 20-23.|Bound in contemporary dark brown calf over thick bevelled boards, tooled in blind (a central tool on top and bottom boards has been erased) with brass corners and the remnants of 4 brass catches.|Purchased with the Philip Hofer Charitable Trust fund and the Bayard Livingston and Kate Gray Kilgour fund, 2006.

Written in a Beneventan script in black ink, 26 long lines per page, initial letters in red. The ms. was probably written at Montecassino.|Another leaf originally forming a bifolium with this one is Schøyen MS 60: see Quaritch.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

subject_as_recorded: Lumbres, Ernulfus de|Crusades--Fifth, 1218-1221|Seninghem (Pas de Calais, France)
physical_description: Extent: 1 leaf (1 box) : vellum ; 18 x 26 cm +
note: Dated June 1220 "ante Damiettam", i.e. with the army of the Fifth Crusade during the siege of Damietta in Egypt.|The 3 original seals depend from the bottom of the document on slips of vellum. They are: (1) in the center 7.4 cm in diameter, Elinardus, showing an equestrian figure on the obverse and arms (indistinct) on the reverse; (2) on the left 4.8 cm, Guillaume de St. Omer, showing his arms; (3) on the right 6.5 cm, Gillebert de Sotinghem, showing arms with a griffin segreant on obverse and reverse.|With a slip of vellum and fragment of seal, with which the document was probably formerly tied up.|Written in a gothic documentary hand in black ink in long lines.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

note: Dated Arles 3 October 1476.|In Middle French.|Written in littera bastarda in long lines in brown ink; signed by the king.|The seal, originally ca. 7 cm in diameter but only partly preserved, is impressed on wax applied to both sides of a horizontal strip partly cut from the lower right-hand corner of the document. It shows the king's arms on the recto, and his image (?) on the verso.|In a box with MS Typ 759.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

subject_as_recorded: Bernardino, da Siena, Saint, 1380-1444--Portraits|Francis, of Assisi, Saint, 1182-1226--Portraits|Anthony, of Padua, Saint, 1195-1231--Portraits
physical_description: Extent: 201 p. in sewn quires : vellum, ill. ; 59 cm.
note: Written in a gothic rotunda book hand in long lines with occasional music in square notation; 58.6 x 40.6 cm.; text 37.5 x 27 cm.|Written and illuminated in Italy, possibly Cremona, in the scriptorium of the brothers Gadio and painted by Baldassare Coldiradi and assistants for a Franciscan (Observant) monastery.|Begins and ends imperfectly; psalter with versicles, responses and hymns (not noted), containing offices for matins and lauds on Thursday, Friday and Saturday, and proper hymns.|12 historiated initials on gold ground, 2 large and numerous decorated initials on gold ground, colored initials in blue and red with penwork flourishes, and 1 foliate border with a historiated medallion : David in prayer (p. 2); a Franciscan monk (p. 10); St. Antony of Padua with a book and a lily (p. 33); St. Francis (pp. 58, 119, medallion); a king in profile (p. 1050; possibly St. Bernardino da Siena (p. 121); and an unidentified monk-saint (p. 126).|In a case, 59 cm.|From the library of Charles Eliot Norton.|Purchase, 1906.

genre_as_recorded: Illuminations|Lectionaries|Manuscripts, Medieval--Italy--1200-1250|Manuscripts, Medieval--Italy--1250-1300|Manuscripts, Medieval--Italy--1500-1550|Manuscripts, Medieval--Italy--1550-1600|Manuscript waste (Binding)--Italy--13th century|Musical notation
physical_description: Extent: 179 leaves, bound : vellum, ill. ; 64 cm.
note: Written in gothic rotunda book hand in long lines with occasional musical notation; 60 x 42 cm., text 40.2 x 26.5 cm. Probably written and illuminated in northern Italy.|One historiated initial of God the Father of "Beatus vir" (f. 3r, matins on Sunday) and four decorated initials (ff. 45v, matins on Monday; 104, matins on Thursday; 130, matins on Friday; 150v, matins on Saturday), all in color on burnished gold ground; smaller 1- and 3-line colored initials with intricate penwork.|Lacks ff. [i], 67, 85.|Front pastedown is lined with a bifolium written in a round Italian gothic book hand from a 13th-cent. office lectionary with lessons for matins on the feast of St. Vincent.|Back pastedown contains alphabetical index of hymns, on paper, added 17th-18th century, damaged.|Bound in its original red leather over thick wooden boards with metal corner pieces and center boss on the front cover.|From the library of Charles Eliot Norton.|Purchased with funds from the Friends of the library, 1905.

title_as_recorded: Succinta et brieve narratione del stato della regina di Scotia et del principe suo figlo
note: Autograph manuscript, signed; dated at Cremona, 26 Jan. 1583.|With prefatory letter : All'illustre Sig[no]r[e] Giovan Battista Alli signor mio sempre Oss[ervatissi]mo".|Text begins: "Maria regina di Scotia figliuola di Iacobo Quinto"; ends: "in questo turbolentissimo tempo. Il fine."|About 30 copies of this text, dedicated to different high-ranking individuals, are currently known (2003).|Bibliographic note in the hand of Luigi Razzolini appears on the front flyleaf.|Bound in brown cloth.|Belonged to Luigi Razzolini.|Gift of Alexander Cochrane, 1906.

Written in a hand resembling littera bastarda in black, with red rubrics and some highlights in blue and yellow.|Title extracted from the "aplogue dudict livre", f. 1r.|Bound with Le verger celeste (printed; Paris, 1537).|On the last page of the printed book, facing f. 1r of the ms., a later hand has written "Traduction de 100 Articles inspirés sur la Passion de N.S. à un Saint Docteur Dominicain en extase devant le crucifix après matines, en Allemagne ..."|Purchased with the Treat fund, 1942.

Written in East Anglia in a gothic book hand in reddish brown ink in two columns, 22 lines per column. 2-line chapter initials are in gold, blue and light red, with foliate decoration; foliated "374" in upper right corner.|Bible ms. broken up by Myers, ca. 1930; this leaf given in 1949 by W. G. Constable to A. R. Sanborn (old cataloging).|Gift of Mrs. Ashton Sanborn, 1974.

The verso has a large historiated initial S showing the descent of the Spirit on the apostles; in silver and colors.|The Latin text is written in a tall gothic book hand, initial letters in blue and red with pen-work decoration. title_as_recorded: Antiphons and prayers for Marian feasts
subject_as_recorded: Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint, in the liturgy
note: Judging by style and codicology, the ms. was probably written in the convent of Cistercian nuns at Medingen, Germany. See curatorial file.|Written in more than one gothic textura book hand in long lines. Initial letters are in various colors with decoration including burnished gold. Some letters are unfinished, having the ground applied but not gilded. There are 9 larger initials with part-borders. Some initials have protective silk veils sewn over them. On. f. 112v the initial is pinned onto the leaf.|Illustrations of figures, all holding scrolls with texts associated with them: Isaiah (f. 25r), two angels (76v, the scroll text being antiphons), David playing the harp and St. Bernard (75r), St. Gregory (80v), St. Ambrose (81r), St. Anselm (106r).|Bound in 18th-century mottled calf, gilt on spine, edges cut down and marbled.|Schenck'sche Fide-Kommiss-Bibliothek (label on front flyleaf with the number 50); Kulturhistorsiches Museum Magdeburg (stamp on end flyleaf).|Purchased with the Bayard Livingston and Kate Gray Kilgour fund, 2006.

The ms. has no date.|Bequest of Philip Hofer, 1984.

In three parts, the first of which (ff. 5r-14v) contains 20 questions and directions to the second part depending on the roll of 3 dice. The third part (ff. 15r-24v) has 20 roundels entitled with signs of the zodiac and Greek gods. Part 3 (ff. 25r-65v) entitled with the names of prophets contains the fortunes in 2-line verses.|A translation, according to the title page, from the French, which was translated from the original book "erstlich in italienischer Sprach beschrieben von Lorenz Geist".|There are numerous watercolor illustrations including (ff. 1v-3v) a gallery of kings.|Bound in original limp vellum stamped with the initials A H Z S C, an unidentified emblem, and the date 1577.|In a tray case, 31 cm.|Purchased with the fund for Printing & Graphic Arts given by Philip Hofer, 1959.

physical_description: Extent: 1 v. (141 leaves, in paper wrappers) in 1 box : vellum ; 27 cm.

Large decorated or historiated initials in red and/or brown with zoomorphic geometric designs, and penwork flourishes appear on ff. 1v, 18r, 27v, 71v (2), 77r, while smaller colored initials occur throughout; rubrics in red and brown. Drawing in light ink of King David playing his harp (f. 19v, margin). Single leaves at the beginning, after ff. 7r, 133r, and end may be lacking; 2 later paper leaves inserted (ff. 91r-92r); trimmed.|Written in Lombardy, perhaps Milan, ca. 1150.|Enclosed in decorative paste paper covers; remains of medieval stitching on 3 leather thongs.|In a box.|Belonged to an unidentified monastery, "Iste liber est [de] monesteri di loco legnate" (f. 126r); Sotheby's, London, 7 Dec. 2004, lot 37.|Purchased with the Bayard Livingston Kilgour and Kate Gray Kilgour fund, and with unrestricted and undesignated funds, 2005.

The manuscript contains many blank pages.|Written for Mark Augspürger (incipit, Simon Köferl vonn Kembnath Burger und Rechenmaister zu Nurmberg Wunsch mark Augspürger von Speir Gluckh und Heyl ... Mein lieber Mark Augspürger hiemit schick Ich euch das Buch ... )|Title derived from caption on f. 1r.|Bound in original stamped pigskin over wooden boards with 2 metal clasps; stamped "M. A. / 1574" on front cover. Front endpapers consist of decorative printed papers with text of Psalm 37 that are inscribed, "Mark Augspürger von Speyer" and "1574".|In a tray case, 35 cm.|Belonged to Mark Augspürger of Speyer; and Paul Edouard Didier, comte de Riant.|Gift of J. Randolph Coolidge and Archibald Cary Coolidge, 1899.

title_as_recorded: Les droys feodaulx extraictz et reduictz dallement en langue romayne ou francoyse /; par moy soubscript. Lan 1532. De Lescut
note: Written in bâtarde script.|Begins, La premiere partie des drois feodaulx. Qui peult bailler fief ou non et comment iceulx seront acquis gardez et retenuz. Premier peullent bailler fiefz les archevesque, evesque.|Bound in modern white vellum.|In a tray case, 32 cm.|Belonged to Paul Edouard Didier, comte de Riant.|Gift of J. Randolph Coolidge and Archibald Cary Coolidge, 1899.

title_as_recorded: The Psalms in Greek, with apparatus of other texts
note: Written by one scribe in a medium-sized calligraphic liturgical minuscule ("hieratic Perlschrift") with slight inclination to the right, typical of mss. of this date.|Date from the beginning date in the Easter tables.|There are 3 full-page miniatures (ff. 8v, 215v, 216v), three headpieces (2 with figural decoration), one anthropomorphic initial letter, and many pen-ornamented initials.|Bound in early 19th-century Russian tan leather.|In a tray case, 27 cm.|Michael Kantakouzenos (ownership inscription dated 1589 on front flyleaf) -- Edward Everett (purchased in Constantinople, 1819).|Gift of Edward Everett, 1820.

Incomplete at the beginning and end. The text comprises Pss 9.15-106.40.|Written by one scribe in a medium-sized calligraphic upright archaizing minuscule hand. The ms. is similar in style to the Palaeologina group but displays less calligraphy and more modest decoration.|On f. 82v there is an unfinished miniature of David (?). Fr. 83v has an illuminated headpiece and initial letter.|The 21 quires are bound in the wrong order. The correct order is 1-9 14-15 13 12 11 10 16-19 21 20.|Bound in 1914 in half brown morocco and marbled paper over boards.|In a tray case, 19 cm.|"From the library of E. Panousis of Constantinople" - old cataloging.|Purchased with the Stephen Salisbury fund, 1909.

title_as_recorded: Regula sanctissimi patris nostri Augustini doctoris eximii
subject_as_recorded: Monastic and religious life--Early works to 1800|Monasticism and religious orders--Germany
note: Title from incipit.|Written in Langnow, Germany, by brother Lucas Villapidanus for Nicolaus Zurn, the prior, in 1522 (colophon, f. 28v).|In an 18th-cent. stiff vellum binding.|In a tray case, 28 cm.|Purchased with the John Harvey Treat fund, 1942.

Title from f. 1r, added in a contemporary hand.|Written in Italy, most likely in Ferrara, in an upright humanist bookhand by two scribes, with contemporary glosses and corrections; one white vinestem initial (f. 1r).|After dedicatory preface to the University of Ferrara and prologue, the text begins: "Prima species ludi. Circa primam ludi speciem cuius finis est .... "|In a 19th- or 20th-cent. green morocco binding by Zaehnsdorf of London.|In a tray case, 18 cm.|Gift of Imre de Vegh, 1949.

Title from incipit, f. 1r: Nel nome dela santissima Trinita incomenza la prima parte di questo sacratissimo libro chiamato Mare Magno dela Crucifissa.|Date from similarity to Venetian bindings of the period (see curatorial file) and ownership notes.|With ca. 250 small and 10 large woodcuts cut out from printed books, partly colored, pasted in.|Written in a very small humanistic hand in black ink in 2 columns (occasionally 1 or 3 columns), rubrics in red in a rotunda gothic hand in 1 column.|Flyleaves at front and back are vellum part-leaves from a ms. apparently of Monaldus, O.F.M., Summa iuris, written in 2 columns in a gothic book-hand, initial letters in blue and red with pen-work decoration.|Bound in contemporary goatskin over paper boards, blind-stamped.|That the author was a Franciscan is likely from his sources, including Ubertino of Casale and Henrico Herp.|See curatorial file for detailed description of the ms. and further discussion of the work.|In a tray case, 24 cm.|Notes on end flyleaf by an owner named Baldassare, recording the birth of his son Bartolomeo in 1557.|Purchased, 2004.

title_as_recorded: Capitula super regula sanctissimi yeronimi ecclesie doctoris eximii
note: Title from incipit.|Written in northeastern Italy or possibly in Spain in a current gothic script, and decorated with one historiated initial, illustrating St. Jerome, and colored initials throughout text.|In a 15th-cent. Italian or Spanish alum-tawed skin binding, stained green.|In a tray case, 20 cm.|Perhaps once owned by the New York dealer Lathrop C. Harper (per Bond and Faye); belonged to Imre de Vegh of New York.|Gift of Imre de Vegh, honorary Curator of Eastern European History and Literature, 1944.

Title from explicit.|Written in southern Italy in Molfetta (prov. Bari), with an interlinear gloss, and completed on 30 Jan. 1466 (colophon, f. 79v). Naples followed the style of the Incarnation so the 1465 recorded in the colophon is actually 1466; one colored initial.|Incorrectly paginated in a modern hand at upper right corner.|In a 16th-cent. Italian vellum over stiff pasteboard.|In a tray case, 24 cm.|Purchased in 1905 by George Dunn (bookplate and inscription); his sale, London, Sotheby's, 2 Feb. 1914 and four following days, no. 1499; to Leighton. Belonged to Imrie de Vegh of New York.|Gift of Imrie de Vegh, 1949.

physical_description: Extent: 200 leaves, bound : vellum, ill. ; 67 cm.

One historiated initial, illustrating the crucifixion; one miniature, representing St. Bernard in prayer (f. 1r); secondary initials in blue and red with pen flourishes.|Bound in contemporary blind-stamped calf with brass bosses.|In a tray case, 24 cm.|Gift of Stanley J. Kahrl, 1975.

title_as_recorded: Daily lectionary of the Gospels in Greek
note: Paginated 1-404. Many leaves are bound in the wrong order (see Boer).|Pp. 1-4, 105-6, 229-32, 399-404 are palimpsest leaves, originally of a ms. of the 10th century.|Written in a professional medium-sized round and clear Perlschrift with inclination to the right. The writing is in 2 columns in brown ink.|Ekphonetic notation is in magenta ink.|There are several small rectangular headpieces in colors, and pen-ornamented initials in magenta ink.|Bound in early 19th-century tan leather over wooden boards, gilt.|In a tray case, 36 cm.|Purchased by Edward Everett in Constantinople, 1819.|Gift of Edward Everett, 1820.

subject_as_recorded: Nazarius, Saint, -68|Gervasius, Saint and Martyr|Protasius, Saint and Martyr|Celsus, Saint, -68
note: Paginated 1-554.|Date according to Kavrus-Hoffman; other opinions given in Mossay.|The contents correspond to those of Vat. Gr. 461.|A vellum flyleaf and another fragment of a leaf laid in come from a ms. (of the 10th century) of the martyrdom of Nazarius, Gervasius, Protasius and Celsus (BHG no. 1323).|Written by one scribe in a professional medium-sized round and clear Perlschrift with inclination to the right. The writing is in black ink in 2 columns.|There is one pi-shaped headpiece (p. 1), and many smaller headpieces. Initial letters are in magenta ink. Major initials are pen-ornamented.|Date from palaeography and resemblance to MS Vat. Gr. 1675. Perhaps written in a monastery in Constantinople.|Bound in early 19th-century tan leather over wooden boards, gilt.|In a tray case, 30 cm.|Purchased by Edward Everett in Constantinople, 1819.|Gift of Edward Everett, 1820.

title_as_recorded: Lectionary of the Gospels in Greek
note: The weekday lections are from John, those for Saturday and Sunday from Matthew and Luke. An index to the lections by a 19th-century scholar (in photocopy) is shelved with the ms.|Written by one scribe in a professional medium-large round and clear liturgical minuscule hand with slight inclination to the right. The writing is in two columns in brown ink.|There are a few small headpieces, wavy division bars, and pen-ornamented initial letters, all in magenta ink. Ekphonetic notation is also in magenta ink.|The ms. probably comes from an outlying province of the Byzantine empire. Earlier cataloging had dated this ms. to the 13th century, but the writing differs from the archaizing scripts of that later time.|Bound in early 19th-century brown leather over wooden boards, gilt. The binding is as vol. 1 of a 2-volume set (kept together as MS Gr 7), but MS Gr 7 vol. 1 was originally a different manuscript.|In a tray case, 30 cm.|Purchased by Edward Everett in Constantinople, 1819.|Gift of Edward Everett, 1820.

title_as_recorded: Luke in the Old Latin version
note: Written in an Irish majuscule script of the second half of the 8th century. The writing is in one column in black ink.|Part of a leaf, cut down for use in a binding. The surviving part is 23 x 17 cm, and contains 25 lines of text on each side, imperfect at the gutter end. The verso is very much faded.|In a cover (formerly guarded in, now loose) of quarter vellum and decorated paper.|In a tray case, 26 cm.|Purchased with the help of Friends of the Harvard College Library and Stanley J. Kahrl, 1978.

title_as_recorded: Lectionary of the Gospels in Greek
note: Written by one scribe in a large vertical majuscule script ("maiuscola ogivale diritta") of the second half of the 10th century. The writing is in 2 columns in brown ink.|Lections begin with colored ornamental initials (ff. 1v and 6v; others have been cut out). Ekphonetic notation is in red dusted with gold.|Bound with quires of paper leaves before and after, in 19th-century Russian tan leather, gilt.|In a tray case, 34 cm.|Purchased by Edward Everett in Constantinople in 1819 (as wrapping for MS Gr 12).|Gift of Edward Everett, 1820.

title_as_recorded: Lectionary of the New Testament Acts and Epistles in Greek
note: Paginated 1-562.|Written by one scribe in a professional medium-sized round and clear liturgical minuscule with slight inclination to the right. There are many flourishes, some decorated with small crosslets or petals. The writing is in 2 columns in brown ink. The script is typical of mss. from Constantinople in the second half of the 11th century. (Earlier cataloging had dated this ms. to the 13th century.)|Ekphonic notation is in magenta ink.|There are four large headpieces (pp. 1, 97, 405, 433) in gold and colors. The headings of each lection are in gold, and the initial letters in gold or colors.|Bound in early 19th-century tan leather over wooden boards, gilt. The binding is as vol. 2 of a 2-volume set (kept together as MS Gr 7), but MS Gr 7 vol. 1 was originally a different manuscript.|In a tray case, 33 cm.|Purchased by Edward Everett in Constantinople, 1819.|Gift of Edward Everett, 1820.

title_as_recorded: Senjas y carta de hidalguia de Diego Ximenes de Ençiso Vizino

The text speaks of three brothers Juan, Geronomo, Diego and Gregorio.|The Spanish text is written in a gothic rotunda hand in black ink between lines and borders ruled in red. The top margin is decorated with pen-work. Written in a spiky gothic book hand in two columns, in black with blue and red initials.|Date from reference in the calendar (25 April) to the coronation of Casimir (1333).|A local origin in Cracow is suggested by the 2 feasts of St. Stanislaus in the calendar: see Wieck.|Each page of the calendar has a miniature illustrating the "occupations of the months", showing peasants doing the work of the season.|Bound in old limp brown morocco, with blind tooling.|In a tray case, 39 cm.|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; gift, 1982.

H. Peerlkamp (signature with date 1803 on front flyleaf); Wilfred Merton (bookplate; purchased from Leighton, catalogue of mss. no. 199).|Purchased with the fund for Printing and Graphic Arts given by Philip Hofer, 1958.

The Latin text is written in littera bastarda in brown ink in one column. title_as_recorded: Institucion de la regla y hermandad de la Cofadria del Sanctissimo Sacramento
note: Written in a gothic rotunda hand in black and red, initial letters with pen-work decoration in red and blue.|F. 1v: "Institucion de la Regla y hermandad dela cofadria del sanctissimo sacramento constituyda enla capilla de senor sant pedro dela sancta yglesia de toledo. Por la muy magnifica fenora dona theresa enrriquez. En el ano del nacimiento de nostro saluador ihu x de mill & quinientos & dos anos."|F. 1v has a miniature showing the arms of the confraternity (the 5 wounds of Christ) and of Sra. Enriquez; f. 2v a full-page miniature of the Last Supper with border including the arms, crest and emblem of Queen Isabella the Catholic; f. 3r a cross with border including arms of the wounds of Christ and keys of St. Peter.|Bound in 18th-century red morocco, gilt, with 2 clasps (one now missing).|In a tray case, 28 cm.|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; bequeathed, 1984.

artist_as_recorded: Marmion, Simon, 1420-1489|Louthe Master|Master of the Dresden Hours, active 1470-1500|Master of the Houghton Miniatures|Ghent Associates of the Master of Mary of Burgundy
former_owner_as_recorded: White, Alfred Tredway, 1846-1921|Van Sinderen, Adrian, 1887-1963|Quaritch, Bernard, 1819-1899|Stirling Maxwell, William, 1818-1878|White, William Augustus, 1843-1927|Emerson, Frances White, 1860-1957
note: The text is written in a gothic rotunda book-hand in one column.|Each page has an outer border panel in tempera and gold in trompe-l'oeil style. Many pages have full borders in this style. There are also 7 miniatures, 14 historiated borders, 28 historiated initials, and 24 calendar illustrations in tempera and gold. (At least 23 further miniatures originally in the ms. are now missing.) The illuminators include the Master of the Houghton Miniatures (named for this ms.), the Ghent Associates of the Master of Mary of Burgundy, the Louthe Master or Simon Marmion, and the Master of the Dresden Prayerbook.|Evidence formerly cited (see Quaritch) to show that the book was written for Queen Juana la Loca of Castile is now interpreted differently.|The texts for the various votive masses are on ff. 51-69 and 128-132.|Both volumes are bound by Zaehnsdorf ca. 1886 in black morocco with an all-over pattern of flowers and the monogram y y.|Vol. 1 has a cloth back and is in a black morocco tray case, vol. 2 in a blue morocco pull-off case, both 16 cm.|The main text of the ms. is in Latin, but at the end (ff. 245v-248r) is "la oracion de Sant Gregorio Papa" in Spanish.|Bernard Quaritch (the whole ms. in 1 volume); Sir William Stirling Maxwell (Quaritch catalogue Sept. 1886 no. 35696), who rebound it in 2 vols.; Quaritch (both vols.)|Vol. 1 (MS Typ 443): William A. White, 1892; his daughter Mrs. Frances White Emerson.|Vol. 1 given in memory of William A. White and his daughter Frances White Emerson by members of their family: Harold White, Donald Moffat, and Mrs. John Wing, 1958.|Bernard Quaritch (the whole ms. in 1 volume); Sir William Stirling Maxwell (Quaritch catalogue Sept. 1886 no. 35696), who rebound it in 2 vols.; Quaritch (both vols.)|Vol. 2 (MS Typ 443.1): Alfred T. White, 1892; his son-in-law Adrian Van Sinderen.|Vol. 2 deposited by Mrs. Adrian Van Sinderen, 1966.

Written in a medium-sized upright calligraphic minuscule, an early "Perlschrift".|There are 5 ornamental canon tables (others are missing), 4 headpieces with floral ornaments, 4 ornamented initials, and minor initials in gold on magenta ink.|Miniatures of the four evangelists (datable to the second half of the 12th century: see Vikan) were tipped into the ms. in ca. the 13th century, replacing sketches in brown ink facing the opening page of each gospel. The miniatures of Matthew and Mark are now shelved separately. That of John is now at Dumbarton Oaks, accession no. 58.105. That of Luke is missing.|Bound in modern white doeskin over thick boards, with 2 leather catches, now broken.|In 2 tray cases labelled "v. 1" for the ms. and "v. 2" for the 2 miniatures (foldered within the case); both 30 cm.|According to a subscription on f. 250r, the ms. was donated to the monastery of the Eleousa, or Nea Mone, by Konstantinos Angelos. The emperor Theodore Komnenos Laskaris is mentioned as having died, hence after 1222.

Written possibly by Sigismondo de Sigismondi, in a small upright humanistic hand in brownish ink, 18 lines per page the initial letters of each line separated into the margin.|The initial leaf of each satire has a miniature in the lower margin and a border, and the first letter of the text in gold. The style of illumination is like that of Monte and Gherardo del Fora. (See curatorial file.)|Bound in old velvet over boards, edges gilt and gauffered.|In a cloth folder within a slipcase, 13 cm.|Thomas E. Marston (bookplate; his sale, London, Sotheby's 11 Dec. 1961, lot 192).|Deposited by Philip Hofer, 1967; bequeathed, 1984.

Illuminated initial P and a floral border containing two roundels (a bird on a branch and a woman seated) and a scroll inscribed "Manus A Hieronim" (f. 1r). 2. Alternating gold and blue headings for the speakers Pallimacro and Filarco in the Deifira (52r-100v, passim). The illuminator is probably Girolama da Cremona.|Binding: early binding in full brown morocco, the front and back tooled in gilt.|In a tray case of full red morocco with raised bands, gilt, 14 cm.

Catchwords on the verso of each leaf. Text is outlined in single crimson border.|Foliated in pencil in Arabic numerals (1-157, 1-16). The second part (1-16) seems to be an appendix added to the book by the author himself. This second part is titled Maqāmāt al-Sayyid ʻAbd al-Qādir al-Kīlānī on fol. 1r.|There are biographies of people in the ms who died after the author, which seem to be later additions.|The ms has stains and smudges throughout.|According to the colophon (fol. 168v), copy completed in the hand of Muḥammad ibn ʻUthmān (?) ... in Shawwāl 974 AH [April 1567 AD].|Several ownership statements with dates on fol. 1r, some of them are deleted. The following could be read: Qāsim ibn Yūsuf, 1085 AH ; ... al-Ḥanafī, 1091 AH ; Muṣṭafá ibn Yūsuf al-Ḥanafī (?) ; al-Shaykh Muṣṭafá al-Saʻdī, 1066 AH (?) ; Aḥmad ibn Ḥasan al-Qūrnaq (?), 1122 AH. There are also 4 seals, two of which are identical, which reads: "al-ʻabd Qāsim yartajī min rabbihi ḥusn al-khitām." One of the other two seals apparently belongs to Aḥmad ibn Ḥasan.|Names of three people who consulted the ms at various times are written on flyleaf of backcover: Salīm ibn Shaykh Ibrāhīm al-Kurdī, in 1230 AH ; ʻAlī ibn Aḥmad kātib Awqāf Salīmīyah, in 1129 AH. Third name is not clear.|"No. 19"--Fol. 1r.|Bound in blind-stamped brown leather over paperboards, with flap. Cream laid paper. Paper size: 20 x 13.5 cm. (Text size: 15 x 7.5 cm.).|Purchased from Mohammad H. Sulaiman, a book dealer in Beirut, in 1970.
